awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Elucidating Chemical Mechanisms of DNA Repair Using Transition State Analogs
awd_abstract_narration:
The information held within the DNA blueprint for life can be eroded by damage to DNA bases due to cellular metabolism and environmental exposures.   Modified DNA bases lead to changes in the DNA sequence called mutations. These mutations can negatively impact cellular processes but they can be corrected by the action of DNA repair enzymes.  With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Sheila David at the University of California Davis and Dr. Martin Horvath at the University of Utah to uncover molecular details of how damaged DNA bases are detected and repaired.   The research makes uses of synthetic DNA chemistry and X-ray crystallography to trap and visualize steps in the DNA repair process that are otherwise too fleeting to study and to generate a detailed molecular picture of the DNA repair process.  Graduate and undergraduate students learn how to combine different chemistry and biology approaches to reveal and understand key features of fundamental life processes. This project is also integrated into a unique "Course-Based Research Experience" (CURE) laboratory course taught at both the University of California Davis and the University of Utah.  Undergraduates emerge from the course with improved critical thinking skills and a better conceptual knowledge of how information crucial for living organisms is encoded in their DNA and maintained by DNA repair enzymes.
 
This research project delineates chemical mechanisms of base excision repair (BER) glycosylases to illuminate how these enzymes efficiently find rare modified DNA bases. Modified nucleotides that mimic transition states are prepared through synthetic chemistry. Structural studies of several BER glycosylases bound to DNA containing these transition state mimics provide insight into the catalysis of base excision. Indeed, surprising features uncovered with three BER glycosylases, namely MutY, AlkD and MBD4, raise new questions on these and related glycosylases and prompt new innovative structural and functional studies that will be pursued by the David and Horvath research groups.  Students working on this project receive interdisciplinary training spanning synthetic nucleic acid chemistry, nucleic acid enzymology, and DNA-protein crystallography. Fostering environments in which women and minority students thrive is a core goal of the work supported by this award. This project has a positive broader educational impact because it is tied to two undergraduate laboratory courses that introduce incoming and advanced undergraduate students to modern research techniques and approaches used in chemical biology with a focus on DNA damage and repair.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: DNA provides a durable storage system for living organisms but is subject to chemical attack putting information at risk. Discoveries made by this project help understand how chemical damage to DNA is repaired by the MutY enzyme. MutY removes adenine when this base is paired with oxidized guanine (OG), and thereby initiates base-excision repair at OG:A lesions to prevent GC to TA mutations. The project defined the chemical mechanism by which adenine is removed. Specifically, the stereochemistry of the enzyme-generated apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) site was determined by direct observation through x-ray structure determination to support a retaining mechanism. Additionally, the region of MutY responsible for identification of OG was pinpointed to three residues (F, S, H) at the tip of a beta-turn within the C-terminal domain (CTD). These advances to understand MutY mechanism were made possible through structure determination of the MutY protein complexed with DNA, and supported by biochemical analyses and by biological assays that measured mutation suppression function for amino-acid replacement variants of MutY. The project also contributed to the search for the evolutionary origins of the OG DNA repair system by functional characterization of MutY homologs found at the Lost City, a hydrothermal field in the Atlantic Ocean where conditions resemble a younger Earth. These discoveries were published in three research articles and coordinates for eight x-ray crystal structures were deposited with the Protein Data Bank (PDB IDs 8dw0, 8dw7, 8dvp, 8dvy, 8dw4, 8dwd, 8dwe, 8dwf). 

 

Broader Impacts: The mechanistic understanding of MutY created by this project also advanced understanding for a whole family of similar DNA repair glycosylases. The project further created a training environment for one graduate student who defended and wrote her PhD thesis and for one URM post-baccalaureate student who is now pursuing her own PhD. Several undergraduates at the University of Utah were also afforded science inquiry opportunities. Some were part of the investigator's research lab and others participated through enrollment in the lab course Molecular Biology of DNA Lab taught by the investigator. A project initiated and led by undergraduates explored the possibility that common medicines may impact MutY function. Support for this idea came from molecular docking experiments demonstrating that medicines fit into crevasses and pockets nearby functionally important regions of the enzyme. Functional evaluation showed further that adapalene, a drug that commonly treats acne, partially inhibits MutY activity in a biochemical assay. Undergraduates in the DNA Lab course fall 2022 generated the data showing that MutYs from the Lost City can suppress mutations in bacteria. A different cohort of students generated the biological data that defined the critical role of FSH residues in the CTD. These opportunities for undergraduates have improved understanding and acceptance of science for a more science friendly society.
